results.address: 6242 Lee Ave N, Minneapolis, MN, 55429, USA
results.raw: Protesters Gathered Overnight After Man Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn Center at 6242 Lee Ave N, Minneapolis, MN, 55429, USA
results.rawLocation: 6242 Lee Ave N, Minneapolis, MN, 55429, USA
results.title: Protesters Gathered Overnight After Man Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn Center

-MY28bbkpwIwOtW3jo2W.text: Incident reported at 6242 Lee Ave N.

-MY28bh3HuwSjYBFS6lw.text: Citizen user video shows a group gathered in the area.

-MY2GReqCAq5iDyGdZnR.text: According to a tweet from the Minnesota Department of Public Safety Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, BCA agents and crime scene personnel are en route to an officer involved shooting incident in Brooklyn Center.

-MY39vAuvBF7t0VXiAUx.text: According to a local news source, Metro Transit is shutting down public transit in Brooklyn Center at the request of law enforcement.

-MY3cvor7ZATksRFwO-Z.text: According to a Tweet from the Minnesota State Patrol, Mobile Response Team units assisted with clearing the area near the Brooklyn Center strip mall. Units are also helping with traffic control.

nib.text:
A 20-year-old man was shot and killed by police during a traffic stop in Brooklyn Center on Sunday after a responding officer discharged their firearm, rather than their Taser, during the stop. 

On Monday afternoon, Brooklyn Center Mayor Mike Elliot and Chief of Police Tim Gannon provided an update on the fatal shooting of 20-year-old Daunte Wright and shared body camera footage from the scene. 

In the footage, the Chief indicated the officer can be heard shouting “taser, taser” before discharging their firearm. Chief Gannon stated that this shouting indicated to him that the officer meant to use their taser, not discharge the firearm. 

"As I watch the video and listen to the officer's commands it is my belief that the officer had the intention to deploy their taser but instead shot Mr. Wright with a single bullet, this appears to me, from what I viewed, and the officer's reaction in distress immediately after, that this was an accidental discharge," Gannon said. 

When asked by a member of the press, Mayor Elliot stated that he supported “releasing the officer of her duties.” 

Chief Gannon indicated that specific details about the officer in question will be released by the Minnesota Department of Public Safety Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) as part of their ongoing investigation. According to Brooklyn Center City Manager Kurt Boganey any disciplinary action will wait until the officer has received due process. 

In an [overnight briefing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gm43yp5ohLU) early Monday morning, John Harrington, the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Public Safety, provided details on what led to the fatal shooting. 

Harrington stated that Wright was pulled over for a traffic violation around 2 p.m Sunday afternoon on Orchard Avenue North. 


During the stop, police learned that Wright had an outstanding warrant and attempted to arrest him. During the attempt, Wright tried to re-enter his vehicle for an unspecified reason. 

The body camera footage shared by Chief Gannon showed a brief struggle as Wright attempted to get back into the vehicle. It is during this struggle that the officer can be heard shouting “Taser, Taser” and discharges her firearm. 

After he was shot, Wright’s vehicle drove several blocks and crashed into another vehicle. 

Wright was pronounced deceased at the scene. A woman who had been in Wright’s car and the other vehicle’s occupants were all transported to an area hospital with minor injuries. 

Commissioner Harrington stated the BCA would be looking at the body camera footage and taking statements but did not provide further information due to their ongoing investigation. 


Protesters had gathered in Brooklyn Center and across the Twin Cities on Sunday in response to the shooting. 

At least 100 people were initially gathered at the scene of the shooting before peacefully dispersing. The [Star Tribune](https://www.startribune.com/brooklyn-center-police-fatally-shoot-man-20-inflaming-tensions-during-the-derek-chauvin-trial/600044821/?refresh=true) reported that Wright’s family members were among the assembled group and offered an account of the shooting different than the one presented by authorities.  

Soon after, officials report that a group of as many as 200 people were gathered at the Brooklyn Center police headquarters. The group allegedly threw rocks and other objects at the building. 

Live video from the headquarters showed police officers lined up across the street as protesters continued gathering in the area. 

Police in the Twin Cities also responded to reports of break-ins and looting throughout the night. Commissioner Harrington noted that officers and members of the National Guard responded to the Shingle Creek Business Center after at least 20 businesses were broken into. 

On Monday morning, the inter-agency group Minnesota Operation Safety Net [announced](https://twitter.com/MinnesotaOSN/status/1381602217694728196) that 500 National Guard personnel were currently activated across the Twin Cities, and that number would increase following Sunday’s officer-involved shooting.

Harrington stated that the operation was moving into Phase 3, a full activation of all state officers, which had been originally reserved for closing arguments and deliberation of the trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

He said the Guard would work with state and local police departments over the next few days to prepare for civil unrest that may come from either the Chauvin trial or the Brooklyn Center shooting.
